review: It works well for Netflix, but Amazon Prime video rarely works if at all.  Lots of skips, stutters frozen screens and won't-loads anytime we try Amazon Prime video, but we have no problems at all with Netflix and Hulu using the Fire Stick.  This is consistent over time, at various times of the day, and using different high-speed internet networks.  I thought this would be great to take advantage of the Amazon Prime video benefit to stream free movies and TV shows, but just as it is with the very unreliable two-day delivery benefit, Prime doesn't deliver value even though the cost has gone up.  If you already get Netflix and other services don't waste your money on this--you don't need it.  If you are expecting this to work well with Amazon Prime, think again.

author: Dan Nelson

review: My Fire Stick was just delivered. After an hour of playing with it, I've all but decided to send it back.First it doesn't use my TV's usb port for power. Had to plug into the old fashion way. Annoying, but not a deal killer.Secondly, and most importantly, the picture and audio quality is substandard. I watched 1 TV show and 2 movies (not all the way through) to test it, and then compared it to blu-ray. The audio is flat and sounds muffled while the picture quality seems to be standard definition even though it shows outputting in high definition. I have solid bandwidth, so I know it's not my connection. I could live with lower picture quality if I'm simply streaming, but the audio killed it for me.Personally, I would not suggest this device. My TV, roku, and PS3 all do a better job. The only reason I picked this up is the roku kills my CEC and the Fire Stick was $20. Not worth it in my opinion
